comments.author: olivine evanescent

comments.text:
Ok, all of these factoids are WRONG!!! Plantains are NOT ripe when green. 
They are yellow-to-black when ripe and they can be just as sweet as 
bananas, just a little firmer. The "yams: pictured in the video are 
actually Korean sweet potatoes, not as sweet, but they are the in same 
genus as the regular orange sweet potato. Real yams are a totally different 
class of root vegetable. A yam looks like a log, hefty and thick, with 
barky skin and a white or yellow flesh. When you cut into it it yields a 
kind of sap like okra. Whole wheat bread IS WHOLE grain ground into flour. 
Whole grain bread is varies from brand to brand. Most of the time it's 
WHITE flour with different whole seed grains tossed in to make it look more 
wholesome--not usually more nutritious than whole wheat. And did you notice 
they threw in some unpopped popcorn in the whole grain example--stupid. 
Green peppers are just unripe sweet peppers. Yellow, orange and red peppers 
are all ripe and very sweet. If you were to let a green pepper ripen it 
would turn yellow orange or red (just not the ones you buy at the store 
because they are usually picked way too early).﻿

comments.author: Ayanna М

comments.text:
+Ayanna М Point is,  plátano is a generic term for banana. I am positive 
plantains and bananas are both called  plátanos in most Spanish speaking 
regions. My Spanish teachers have been Chilean, Spanish, Mexican, Cuban and 
none of them say "banana" as a Spanish word. Always  plátano. My Spanish 
exchange student explicitly told me never to call them "bananas" because 
that's English.

comments.text:
Yellow bananas are not ripe yet. They'll cause constipation and dehydration 
when eaten like that. Bananas are ripe when they are covered in brown 
spots- that's when the starches have converted to sugars and the banana 
becomes sweet.
Also plantains are ripe when the peel is completely black, and they're 
eaten cooked.﻿

comments.author: Mays Clan

comments.text:
Farmers began selling peppers green during the great depression. People 
desperately needed the food, and the farmers desperately needed the cash, 
so they began selling the unripened peppers. Turns out, people actually 
liked them (and they have a much different taste). Afterwards, as the 
depression ended, they continued selling the unripe ones, as well as the 
ripe ones.

The yellow, red, and orange ones are more expensive because it takes much 
longer for them to be harvest-able, so farmers/companies charge more for 
them. Because they charge more for them, the store charges more for them. 
Yellow, orange, and red peppers are sweeter than green peppers because 
they've spent more time on the plant, and built up those sugars. They are 
berries, after all.

comments.author: Esor♥

comments.text:
This is incorrect. Yellow bell peppers are also fully matured and ripened. 
Some varieties of bell peppers that are green when immature turn red when 
they are fully mature, and some naturally turn yellow. The yellow ones are 
just as mature as the red ones are. They are just naturally maturing to a 
different color. I grow bell peppers for market, so I know what I'm talking 
about. There are also white bell peppers, those change to red when fully 
mature, and ones that start green and change to orange when mature, and 
ones that are purple when immature and they also change to red when fully 
mature.﻿
